message:
strategy A: use esk, and create a directory with your username in it. (this is what I do).
strategy B: insert esk into your existing setup, if you have one.

If you're new to emacs, use A. Most who aren't use B.
long term is to just steal the bits of it you want.
its rare that you'll want everything in the ESK

Chances are you don't want everything in the ESK. The point is to be lean and powerful. Use only the customizations that you need and will actually use. Long term means removing cruft early before it becomes a problem.

I started with emacs starter kid as a starting point and have customized it considerably. It's worked pretty well for me, though it is true that I should go through and disable a bunch of bloat that I don't use (as it is, I've only disabled things that actively got in my way). Here's my fork: https://github.com/jackowayed/emacs-starter-kit

I started by having my own fork of ESK, but recently Phil simplified the setup considerably. Now I just keep my own emacs customizations in a separate repo and symlink custom.el and vendor/ into .emacs.d.
I forked ESK, most of my customizations are in "ramen": https://github.com/ramen/emacs-starter-kit
Overall I think it has a lot of good sane defaults, does nice auto-loading and byte-compiling, and pushed me in a few modern directions such as using ido
I learned that I really don't jive with paredit, and a few other things bug me, like ELPA being super out of date, and no obvious way to incorporate git submodules instead
@ramen You might check out marmalade http://marmalade-repo.org/
